children.name: to win a race, competition etc
win a2
children.definition: win towina race, competition, election etc, for example by getting more points, votes etc than everyone else or by being the first to finish:chiến thắng
examples: ▪ no-one really expected the socialist party to win.
win a race/game/election etc
▪ chang won the first set but lost the next two.
▪ the competition was won by a nigerian student.
win a prize/medal/cup etc
▪ his book won the pulitzer prize for literature.
▪ what would you do if you won $1 million?
win by 6 votes/2 goals etcwin by getting 6 votes etc more than the other person or team : thắng hơn bao nhiêu phiếu/điểm...
▪ he went ahead of nolan, winning by 15 seconds.
win 4-2/20-12 etcuse this to show the final result of a game :
▪ do you remember our first game of the season? we won 3-1.
win at cards/chess/tennis etc
▪ she always wins at scrabble.

children.name: finish first b1
children.definition: finish first/be first/come in firstalsocome firstuk  to win a race or competition in which more than two people or teams are competing:
examples: ▪ who do you think will finish first?
▪ the british team was first, followed closely by the americans.
▪ andré etienne came in first, having completed the course in record time
finish first/be first/come in first in
▪ an australian runner came first in the marathon.
▪ sue finished first in two races -- the 50m backstroke and the 100m front crawl.

children.name: first place b1
children.definition: first/second/etc place  the position of the person or team that wins a race or competition:
examples: in first/second/etc place
▪ johnson finished in first place, narrowly ahead of green.
win first/second/etc place in
▪ my greatest achievement was winning first place in the young artist competition.

children.name: get in b2
children.definition: get in british if apoliticalpartygetsin, they win an election, and have the right to form a government:thắng
examples: do you think labour will get in again at the next election?

children.name: to win a fight, war, argument, etc
win a2
children.definition: win/wɪn/  to argue, fight etc more successfully than someone else:
examples: chiến thắng
▪ the court case has been dragging on for months, and it’s increasingly unlikely that she’ll win.
▪ i could never win an argument with my father.
▪ who won the first civil war?
win a victory
▪ this was the first of many victories won by women’s rights campaigners.

children.name: come out on top u
children.definition: come out on top informal to win sth, especially sth that other people arejudgingordeciding:
examples: ▪ in a survey of customer preference, one model came consistently out on top.
▪ in all action movies, the hero always comes out on top.

children.name: prevail c2
children.definition: prevail formal if anideaorway of doing sthprevails, it is finally accepted as being better or more important than something else, especially after a lot of arguing:thắng thế
examples: ▪ fortunately, in this case, common sense has prevailed.
prevail over
▪ she seems to think that animal rights should prevail over everything else.

children.name: carry the day x
children.definition: carry the day/ˌkæri ðə ˈdeɪ/  british to win by persuading people to accept a plan, proposal, or idea, especially after a lot of talking and arguing:
examples: chiến thắng ( nói về một kết hoạch, ý tưởng sau khi thuyết phục mọi người )
▪ anti-gun campaigners feel they have enough support to carry the day in tomorrow’s vote.
▪ his appeal to reason and common sense was what finally carried the day.

children.name: win the day x
children.definition: win the day/ˌwɪn ðə ˈdeɪ/  british to finally win an argument or political struggle, especially when this has beendifficult - used especially innewsreports:
examples: chiến thắng ( nói về một cuộc tranh luận, đấu tranh chính trị , thường dùng trên báo )
▪ on this occasion the strikers won the day and were given a pay increase of 20%.

children.name: to be winning a game, race etc that has not yet finished
be winning a2
children.definition: be winning to have more points or votes than your opponents in a game or election, or to be at the front in a race when the game, race etc has not yet finished:đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: ▪ senna was winning when the race was brought to a halt because of a crash.
be winning sth
▪ it looked as though bush was winning the election battle.

children.name: lead b2
children.definition: lead/be in the leadb2 to be winning a game, race, election etc:đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: the high school team were leading with 60 points.
the dolphins are still in the lead with only 2 minutes left to play.
lead by 10 points/three meters etc
agassi was leading by two sets when rain stopped play.

children.name: ahead b2
children.definition: be ahead to be doing better than sb else in a game, competition, race, or election:đang dẫn đầu, đang thắng
examples: ▪ she was still ahead in the polls just a week before the election.
be ahead of
▪ waylan was ahead of miller by three shots.
put sb ahead
▪ shortly afterwards smith put the dodgers ahead with a stunning home run.
be 12 points/5 games etc ahead
▪ damon hill is now 14 points ahead of his nearest rival.
by way ahead
▪ by the final lap, molly was way ahead of all the other girls.
be ahead by 12 points/5 games etc
▪ houston was ahead by 3 points at half-time.

children.name: the result of a game, competition, or election
result
children.definition: /rɪˈzʌlt/  the final number of points, votes etc at the end of a competition, election etc. in british english, result can also be used to talk about the end of a game or sports match:
examples: ▪ it was a really exciting game, and the result was 2-1 to west germany.
▪ these are excellent results for the christian democratic party.

children.name: score
children.definition: /skɔːʳ/  the number of points that each team has at the end of a game or competition:
examples: điểm số
▪ at the end of the game, the score was 32-15.
what’s the score :điểm số thế nào rồi ?
▪ what was the score?
final score:điểm chung cuộc
▪ the final score was 2-1 to juventus.

children.name: second a1
children.definition: secondordinal number,determiner
examples: the position in which a person finishes a race or competition if they finish immediately behind the winner
_first prize is a fortnight inbarbadosand secondprizeis a weekend inrome.
_jones took secondplacein the long jump.

children.name: second b1
children.definition: secondadverb
examples: after the first and before any others
_robertson won the race and cameronwas/came/finishedsecond.
_in this business, money comes first and principlescomea verypoorsecond (= they are much less important) .

children.name: come after/first/last, etc. b1
children.definition: come after/first/last, etc.
examples: to have or achieve a particular position in a race, competition, list, etc.
_sheukcame second/uscameinsecond in the 100m race.
_z comesaftery in the alphabet.
_which king cameafteredward?
_april comesbeforemay.
_i know the first verse of the song, but i don't know what comesnext.

children.name: lead b2
children.definition: leadverbled,ledbe winning dẫnđầu
examples: [ i or t ] (especially in sport or other competitions) to be in front, to be first or to be winning
_after thirty minutes the challengers were leadingbytwo goals.
_with two laps to go ngomo ledbyless than two seconds.
_the lions lead the hawks 28 - 9.

children.name: lead b2
children.definition: leadnounbe winning vị trí đứng đầu
examples: [ s ] a winning position during a race or other situation where people are competing
_for the first time in the raceharrisonisinthe lead.
_with a final burst of speed shewent/moved intothe lead.
_after last night's win johnson hastaken (over)the lead in the championship table.
_by the end of the day's play davies had a leadofthree points.

children.name: knock sb out b2
children.definition: knocksboutphrasal verbdefeat
examples: to defeat a person or a team in a competition so that they can no longer take part in it
_the champion was unexpectedly knocked out (ofthe tournament) in the first round.

children.name: come in first/second, etc x
children.definition: come in first/second, etc.về vị trí thứ…
examples: to finish a race in first, second, etc. position

children.name: victory b2
children.definition: victory when a country, player, team etc wins a battle, game, race etc:chiến thắng
examples: the crowds were celebrating italy’s victory.
we’re very confident of victory.
victory over/against
the raiders’ 35–17 victory over st louis
victory for
the court’s decision represents a victory for all women.
a great/major victoryhe said the court’s decision was a great victory.
an easy victoryarsenal expected an easy victory.
a decisive victorythe battle was a decisive victory for the us.
a landslide victory(= a win by a very large amount in an election )no one had anticipated such a landslide victory.
a crushing victory(= a win by a very large amount )australia won a crushing 139-run victory over the west indies.
a narrow victory(= a win by a small amount )a general election on oct. 5 produced a narrow victory for the people’s progressive party.
an election/electoral victorythe democrats were celebrating their election victory.
a military victoryone of the general’s most famous military victories
a moral victory(= when you show your beliefs are right, even if you lose the argument )the victims’ families claimed the verdict as a moral victory.
win/score a victorytoday we have won an important victory.
lead somebody to victoryshe led her team to victory in the finals.
clinch victory(= finally win )adams scored a last-minute goal to clinch victory.
pull off a victory(= win when it is difficult )martin pulled off a surprise victory in the semi-final.
sweep to victory(= win easily )nixon swept to victory by 47 million votes to 29 million.
victory celebrationsthe victory celebrations went on all night.
a victory paradethey intend to hold a victory parade.
a victory lap(= when a winning runner or player runs around the playing area )he then took a victory lap around the arena.
a string of victories(= a series of victories )the team won a string of victories.
common errors
►do not say'get victory'or'get the victory'. saywin a victoryorwin victory.

children.name: win c1
children.definition: win when a team or playerwinsin a sport or competition - used especially innewsreports:
examples: we’ve had two wins so far this season.
it was united's sixth consecutive win this season.
everyone was predicting a republican win at the last election and look what happened.
win over
in the under-16 event england had their first win over germany.
a big win(= an important win, or one that you win by a large amount )this is one of the biggest wins i’ve had.
an easy winthe australian appeared to be heading for an easy win.
a comfortable win(= one that you win by a large amount, so that you do not have to worry about winning )chelsea had a comfortable win against crystal palace.
a convincing winespecially british english(= a win by a large amount )scotland cruised to a convincing win over ireland.
a five-point/two-goal etc winthe team had a nine-point win over arizona.
have/score a winwe haven’t had a win for three games.
notch up a win(= achieve a win )escude has now notched up three consecutive wins over him.
pull off a win(= win when it is difficult to win )the side has pulled off two excellent wins in the past couple of weeks.
clinch a win(= finally win after a difficult contest )he suffered some anxious moments before clinching a 9–6 win over dennis taylor last night.
cruise to a win(= win easily )arsenal cruised to a win over chelsea.

children.name: triumph c1
children.definition: triumph written an important victory after a long, difficult struggle, especially in war or politics:chiến thắng
examples: despite many local triumphs, their party stands little chance of winning a national election.
arsenal’s recent league cup triumph.
winning the championship is a greatpersonal triumph.
triumph for
a tremendousdiplomatic triumphfor france
triumph over
the triumph over hardship

children.name: success u
children.definition: success/səkˈses/  a victory, especially in a series of games, fights etc:
examples: thành công , chiến thắng ( đặc biệt trong 1 chuỗi trò chơi, cuộc chiến )
▪ with such a strong team, france are heading for certain success.
▪ their fourth success in a row

children.name: conquest x
children.definition: conquest a victory in which one country wins a war against another countryand takes controlof it:chinh phục
examples: ▪ the palace was built in cordoba, spain, following the arab conquest.
▪ the roman legions left, opening the way for the conquest of the british isles by the germanic tribes.

children.name: walkover x
children.definition: walkover informal a situation in which someone wins veryeasily, especially in a sport, because they are much better than the people they are playing against:chiến thắng dễ dàng
examples: ▪ if they were expecting this game to be a walkover, they were very wrong.

children.name: landslide x
children.definition: landslide when one party or candidate getsfar morevotes than their opponents in anelection:thắng lớn
examples: ▪ the newspapers were predicting a landslide for thatcher.
by a landslide
▪ he was re-elected in 1984 by a landslide.
landslide victory
▪ few people had expected labour’s landslide victory in 1945.

children.name: win easily a2
children.definition: win easily/ˌwɪn ˈiːzli/
examples: ▪ everyone expected the democrats to win easily.
win something easily
▪ she won the race easily with seconds to spare.

children.name: win hands down x
children.definition: win hands down/wɪn ˌhændz ˈdaʊn/  to win very easily without having any problems:
examples: thắng dễ dàng
▪ the socialists will win hands down if the election is free and fair.
▪ the newer model wins hands down when it comes to speed and capacity.

children.name: be no contest u
children.definition: be no contest/biː ˌnəʊ ˈkɒntestǁ-ˈkɑːn-/  if a game, competition etcis no contest, one person or team wins so easily that it is impossible for their opponent to win:
examples: ▪ in the end it was no contest. new labour won more votes than even they thought possible.

children.name: run away with x
children.definition: run away with/ˌrʌn əˈweɪ wɪð/  to win a game or competition very easily, especially because you are much better than your opponents:
examples: chiến thắng ( dễ dàng vì mạnh hơn )
▪ united have esta blished a clear lead, and are threatening to run away with the championship.

children.name: be a shoo-in x
children.definition: be a shoo-in/biː ə ˈʃuː ɪn/  american to be verylikelyto easily win an election, competition etc, by having many more points, votes etc than you opponents:
examples: là người chiến thắng ( rất có thể do đang chiếm được nhiều điểm, phiếu.. hơn )
▪ he looked like a shoo-in to win south carolina’s republican presidential primary.

children.name: sweep to victory x
children.definition: sweep to victory to win very easily, in a way thatimpressespeople - used especiallyinnewsreports:thắng ngoạm mục, “lướt”
examples: ▪ olson scored twice as the rams swept to victory.
▪ nixon swept to victory by 47 million votes to 29 million.

children.name: romp home x
children.definition: romp home british informal to win a race or game easily:thắng dễ dàng
examples: ▪ no goals were scored in the first half but spurs romped home in the second, scoring four.

children.name: to win when you almost lost
win by a narrow margin x
children.definition: win by a narrow margin if sb wins sth or is electedby a narrow margin, they win by getting only a few more points, votes etc than their opponent: thắng suýt sao
examples: we won the debate by a narrow margin.
winning by a narrow margin, the lakers now go on to play in the championships.

children.name: scrape home x
children.definition: scrape home uk to win by a very small number of votes or points, or by a very small distance in a race:thắng suýt sao
examples: the green party scraped home in the local elections.
the referees decided that foreman had just scraped home.

children.name: be close u
children.definition: be closealsobe a close-run thinguk  if a race, competition, election etc is close or is a close-run thing, any person or party could win because they all have nearly the same number of points, votes etc, or are close to each other in the race:gay cấn
examples: the election was very close - a handful of votes decided it.
the champions have kept their title, but it was a close-run thing

children.name: to be the one most expected to win
favourite c2
children.definition: be (the) favouritebritish /be the favoriteamerican /biː (ðə) ˈfeɪvərt/  to be the person or team that everyone expects to win:
examples: be (the) favourite for
▪ the danish runner was the favorite for the 100m sprint.
be (the) favourite to win
▪ thatcher was favourite to win the 1983 election.
be (the) clear favourite
▪ the luxembourg entry is clear favourite to win the eurovision song contest.d

children.name: frontrunner x
children.definition: frontrunner/ˌfrʌntˈrʌnəʳ/  the person or team that is most likely to win a race, election, or competition:
examples: người , đội có tiềm năng chiến thắng
▪ he will certainly be a frontrunner in the democratic primaries.
▪ the greens have never really been among the frontrunners in british politics.

children.name: in the running x
children.definition: be in the running/biː ɪn ðə ˈrʌnɪŋ/  to be one of the people whohas a good chanceof winning:
examples: là người có cơ hội chiến thắng
▪ spain still has several athletes in the running.
be in the running for
▪ anthony hopkins was in the running for an oscar.
